docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress prepares to consider landmark legislation intended to reduce underage tobacco use, a growing number of states, cities and schools are taking measures to crack down on what they see as a major cause of the problem: young people themselves. Over the past year, states like Florida, Idaho, Minnesota, North Carolina and Texas have passed laws that could result in stiff penalties for minors who try to buy or possess cigarettes or chewing tobacco. Those convicted of such offenses could lose their driver's licenses, face fines of up to $1,000 or even be imprisoned for up to six months.

headline.main: STATES AND CITIES IMPOSE NEW LAWS ON YOUNG SMOKERS

docs.abstract: As Congress weighs landmark legislation intended to reduce underage tobacco use, growing number of cities and schools are taking measures to crack down on what they see as major cause of problem, namely, young people themselves; over past year, Florida, Idaho, Minnesota, North Carolina and Texas have passed laws that could result in stiff penalties for minors who try to buy or possess cigarettes or chewing tobacco; some cities are using undercover police officers to catch youths who smoke, and some schools tha test students for illegal substances are also screening them for nicotine; new measures follow failure of repeated efforts in recent years to use educational programs and other measures to halt growth in number of minors who use tobacco; while many anti-smoking advocates support toughened approach, others see new state laws, many of which are backed by tobacco industry, as draconian response to custom that was once teen-age rite of passage; photo (M)
